awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Humans, Water, and Climate: Advancing Research and Education on Water Resource Sustainability in Managed Land-Water Systems using Integrated Hydrological Modeling Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
A critical challenge in sustainable water resource management is to ensure adequate supply of water to meet the rapidly growing demands for food, energy, and water, while minimizing negative social, environmental, and ecological impacts. Striking this balance requires a clear understanding of the human-induced changes in freshwater flows and storages, agricultural systems, and ecosystem services, as well as the complex interactions and feedback among coupled natural and human systems. The goal of this project is to advance the research and education of water resource sustainability in managed land-water systems by using a novel numerical modeling framework and a wealth of data from ground and satellite observations, climate models, and socio-economic analysis. The framework, which comprises of a suite of hydrological, agricultural, and ecological models, is used to identify ways to optimize the use of land and water resources by systematically examining the trade-offs between upstream basin management for food-energy production (e.g., hydropower, irrigation) and downstream changes in river-floodplain dynamics and groundwater systems (e.g., reduction in sediment load, seawater intrusion). The project will provide new insights about ways to best utilize the information on global change and practices for local-regional water management through its integration into coupled hydrological-agricultural-ecological models to develop adaptation strategies for sustainable water resource management as well as achieving water and food security. The research project integrates a substantive set of educational initiatives for promoting knowledge about hydrology and water resources among high school and community college students, motivating them to pursue STEM education and inspiring them to study freshwater systems toward addressing pressing societal challenges regarding food, energy, and water security. The educational component involves an interactive web-based version of the modeling system for classroom use in undergraduate and graduate teaching, for educating high school and community college students, and as resource for teachers especially in community colleges. The education program also includes mentored international research and training through online initiatives. 

The modeling framework is based on the Community Land Model (CLM) but includes critical enhancements made by incorporating advanced schemes representing crop growth, irrigation, groundwater pumping, and river-floodplain-reservoir routing. The strength of this novel framework lies in its ability to explicitly resolve the coupled behavior of a range of natural hydrologic and biophysical processes (e.g., surface hydrology, groundwater dynamics, sediment transport, land use change, and crop growth), human land-water management practices (irrigation, reservoir operation, groundwater pumping), and ecological processes (seawater intrusion, floodplain-wetland dynamics). The framework is designed to simulate large-scale water cycle dynamics at regional to continental scales while also mechanistically resolving fine-scale, topography-driven hydrologic-groundwater processes such as lateral groundwater flow and river-floodplain-groundwater interactions. Thus, the study will significantly advance our capability to simulate coupled surface water, groundwater, and agricultural systems, which is critical for achieving food security through better assessment and prediction of water resource. Since CLM is a land component of an Earth System Model (ESM), the new framework and insights gained from the study are expected to inform the development of the next generation of ESMs through the incorporation of human components for the holistic study of coupled natural-human systems, and to assess human-climate interactions. The new framework will also enable us to better assess and predict water resources in highly managed land-water system around the world including the High Plains in the central US and Central Valley in California where declining water supplies are likely to adversely impact regional, national, and global food security in the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this CAREER project is to advance research and education of water resource sustainability in managed land-water systems by using a novel and comprehensive modeling framework that encompasses a suite of hydrological, agricultural, and ecological models, and exploits a wealth of data from ground and satellite observations, climate models, and socio-economic studies. By improving the simulation of coupled natural-human systems, the project aims to better capture the dynamics of underlying natural, physical, biological, and human processes toward better predicting the complex interactions and feedback among them and informing decision making for sustainable resource management. To that end, the project provided major advances in our ability to model human interventions of the water cycle by incorporating irrigation, reservoir operation, and groundwater withdrawal into land surface models (LSMs) and applying the newly integrated model over various global regions that are intensively managed. The project also led to substantial educational, outreach, and international mentorship activities. The key outcomes include the following.

(1) Human interventions (e.g., irrigation and groundwater withdrawal) were incorporated into an LSM, the Community Land Model (CLM5), leading to a comprehensive modeling system to simulate land-water management across a range of spatial and temporal scales. The new model was also coupled with the parent Earth system model (ESM), enhancing the ability to simulate human systems within ESMs.

(2) A global river-floodplain routing model CaMa-Flood was enhanced by incorporating a newly developed reservoir operation model; the new framework is capable of simulating natural rivers, floodplains, and man-made reservoirs within a single, consistent framework. The framework that combines CLM5 with human interventions and CaMa-Flood with reservoirs was applied over the Mekong River basin, Amazon River basin, and the Continental US to examine the combined impacts of human interventions and climate change on water resources, agriculture, and ecological systems. The research findings on the Mekong and Amazon River basins provided critical novel insights on how existing and planned dams across the basins would undermine natural hydrologic dynamics, ecosystems, and local livelihoods.

(3) The project generated over 30 peer-reviewed publications, including several in interdisciplinary journals such as Nature and Science; key outcomes presented in these publications were included in the Sixth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and a country report on climate change published by the World Bank. Outcomes also featured in various national and international news outlets, among which was an article that appeared in 'The Conversation', which was eventually included in an anthology published by the Johns Hopkins University. While some of the publications resulted from core research activities, others were an outcome of significant international collaborations developed through this project. Over two dozen presentations, including invited talks and seminars, were given at various scientific conferences and universities, both nationally and internationally. 

(4) The project partially or fully supported six PhD students, three masters students, several undergraduate students, one international exchange student, and two postdoctoral scholars. Some of the students were female or underrepresented and many received various awards and scholarships (both internal and external to the university).

(5) The project also produced substantial outreach by engaging with Community College educators across the US Midwest, contributing to curriculum enhancement through integration of emerging topics related to global environmental change and food-energy-water security.

(6) The project engaged over 200 high school students, providing them with critical learning experience on the importance of water resource sustainability in a changing global environment.

(7) The project provided opportunities to build substantial new international collaborations, which resulted in over a dozen journal publications and helped the PI to develop new research and educational initiatives. The PI was also able to win the US Fulbright Senior Scholar Award by leveraging the international networks developed through the project.
